prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together. He pays all the bills because she's only working part-time. They had an incident where he left his wallet, so he asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She had a bad attitude, and now he's considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

First, I need to analyze both sides. The author is frustrated because he's covering all expenses, and this one incident made him feel like she's not contributing. But is that a valid reason to make her start paying? Let's break it down.

He mentions she works part-time. Maybe her income is lower, so expecting her to take on more bills might be unfair if her earnings aren't sufficient. The takeout was a small amount, so her reaction seems out of proportion. However, he's generalizing from one incident. Maybe she was stressed or had other issues that day. Also, splitting bills isn't just about money; it's about shared responsibility. If they're a couple, it's reasonable to split costs unless they've agreed on a different arrangement. But he's been paying everything up until now. Changing the dynamic suddenly over a minor incident could be seen as unfair, especially if her income isn't enough. 

He might be overreacting because of the incident, using it as a catalyst to shift responsibilities. The question is whether he's in the wrong. If he's been covering all bills because of their current financial situations, and now he's using a small event to make her pay without considering her income, that could be his mistake. On the other hand, if he feels it's about principle and fairness, but the approach is abrupt, that's problematic. 

So, the answer might depend on whether he's considering her financial situation and communication. If he's making her pay without discussing it and without considering her ability, he's in the wrong. The incident might be a symptom of deeper issues, but using it as a reason to shift responsibilities without context could be unfair. Therefore, the answer is likely A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
